div.div:
Forord
Da “Fra mand til kvinde”[Sic.] In the original title “Mand” and “Kvinde” have an initial capital, but this is consistent with the orthography of 1988. udkom i 1931, var den yderst kontroversiel. Bogens emne, transsexualitet, har været ukendt for flertallet af datidens læsere, der utvivlsomt har betragtet den som en pikant historie.
En transsexuel person er uvenner med sit biologiske køn. Han ønsker at skifte køn og er som Andreas Sparre i denne bog villig til at gennemgå alle mulige indgreb, operative, medicinske og kosmetiske, der kan ændre hans udseende og fremtoning. For Andreas Sparre er situationen den, at han med hensyn til kønsidentitet – forstået som den opfattelse en person har af sig selv som tilhørende det ene eller det andet køn, uanset hvilken kønsrolle man udadtil præsenterer – føler sig som 100% kvinde, der ved en “fejl” er blevet anbragt i en mands krop.
Spørgsmålet om kønsidentitet har i dag fået fornyet aktualitet, og interessen for den yderste del af kønsidentitetens spektrum – de intersexuelle, transvestitter og transsexuelle – er stigende. Afgrænsningen af det kvindelige og det mandlige har altid optaget menneskeheden, men er i vor tid blevet forbundet med en voksende narcissisme – i andre sammenhænge karakteriseret som det moderne menneskes svaghed.
“Kroppen er ikke en genstand, den er en situation”, skrev den franske filosof Merleau-Ponty, og vi har allesammen oplevet, hvordan kroppen har en speciel betydning i forholdet til sine omgivelser.
Menneskets krop kan blive til en forbandelse gennem opdragelse og miljø. Det ses specielt tydeligt hos transexuelle mennesker, som denne bogs hovedperson, der er dømt til at have en krop og ikke være en krop.
Men det er ikke kun mennesker, der har problemer med at definere grænsen mellem det mandlige og det kvindelige. “Gud”, sagde den jødiske fortæller, skabte mennesket i sit eget tvekønnede billede. Som mand og som kvinde skabte han dem, for i ham var de begge forenede.
Bogens mandlige hovedperson, Andreas Sparre, hed i virkeligheden Einer [Sic.] Wegener. Han var kunstmaler og gift med den kendte illustrator Gerda Wegener – i bogen kaldet Grete.
I forbindelse med Einer Wegeners forestående kønsskifteoperation blev han som beskrevet i bogen undersøgt på Institut für Sexualwissenschaft
Einar og Gerda Wegener i deres hjem. De giftede sig i 1904. Einar Wegener var født i 1882. Politikens Presse Foto. The photo is at the top of the page and is credited to Politiken Press. It shows Einar and Gerda Wegener sitting in chairs a few feet apart in a room in their home that is filled with art and books.
i Berlin. Grundlæggeren af dette verdens første sexologiske institut var professor key="hirschfeld">Magnus Hirschfeld, som i bogen kaldes Hardenfeld. Han var pioner indenfor den sexologiske forskning – i Amerika omtalt som “Einstein of Sex” – og midtpunkt i et særegent og farverigt miljø. På hans institut flokkedes en række af datidens store kulturpersonligheder, bl.a. forfatteren Christopher Isherwood, som omtaler Hirschfeld og hans institut i erindringsbogen“Christopher og hans kreds”. I øvrigt bygger filmen “Caberet” på samme Isherwoods skildringer fra Berlin.
Da Hirschfeld foruden sexolog tillige var jøde, pacifist, socialist og homosexuel, blev han hurtigt offer for nazistisk forfølgelse og måtte søge landflygtighed. Instituttet blev i 1933 stormet af nazisterne, arkiverne brændt og indboet ødelagt. Mange husker sikkert de dokumentariske filmoptagelser fra 30’ernes Berlin, hvor de fanatisk skrigende nazizter bærer en buste af Magnus Hirschfeld til bålet.
Lili Elbe og en sygeplejerske på Frauenklinik i Dresden efter kønsskifteoperationen. Det kongelige Biblioteks billedsamling. The photo, which takes up the whole page along with the caption, is credited to The Royal Library, The Collection of Prints and Photographs. It shows Lili Elbe dressed in dress, pumps, and hat outside the Frauenklinik in Dresden with a nurse after surgery.
Einer Wegener fik foretaget den endelige kønsskifteoperation på Frauenklinik i Dresden, og under navnet Lili Elbe vendte hun derefter tilbage til Danmark. Her mødte hun den tyske forfatter Ernst Harthern, der som udenrigskorrespondent havde bosat sig i København. Harthern påtog sig, som nævnt i bogens forord, hvor han underskrev sig Niels Hoyer, at samle Lili Elbes optegnelser med henblik på en bogudgivelse. Hans datter, Ruth Hanna Harthern-Thaning, som også omtales i bogen, var dengang 16 år. Hun fortæller følgende om Lili Elbe:
“Ja, det var ikke hendes ydre fremtoning (ræverødt hår, knaldrøde negle og mund). Nej, det var hendes ganske væsen --- hun var en ægte kvinde. For jeg havde ikke kendt hende som mand. Det blev aftalt (Lili Elbe følte sig meget ensom, forstod jeg), at jeg skulle lære at male hos hende. Det var pinseThis letter is also included in Hertoft’s and Ritzau’s text in Paradiset er ikke til salg where Pinse (Whitsun) is written with a capital P. næste dag. Næste morgen forlod jeg vores bolig i Havnegade 47. Let om hjertet gik jeg gennem den solbeskinnede Nyhavn til Kongens Nytorv og kørte videre med sporvogn til Valby, hvor denne Elbe havde søgt ly i en kvistlejlighed hos pæne mennesker i en pæn villa. Hun havde allerede sat et staffeli frem, hvorpå der var placeret et færdigstrukket lærred, desuden var der farve, og hvad der ellers hørte til at male.
På de få dage i hendes liv blev det til et selvportræt og to stilleben. Det var sikkert også af andre grunde, at hun lod mig komme indenfor, the det arme menneske havde forelsket sig stærkt i sin velgører: professorenWritten with a capital P in Paradiset er ikke til salg. fra “Frauenklinik” i Dresden.
Frygteligt sørgeligt. Det var godt, jeg allerede dengang så klart forstod, at man ikke kan sende sådanne breve. Hvad denne læge havde gjort med den operation var måske slet ikke så godt for dette ulykkelige menneske. Hun havde en evig kamp med sig selv.
Jeg skammede mig, troede hun, når jeg oversatte hendes kærlighedsbreve til ham fra dansk til tysk. I virkeligheden ændrede jeg dem til kun at være venlige takkebreve. Naturligvis måtte det være ubehageligt for lægen. Det blev ikke til mange breve.
Pludselig bad hun mig om ikke at komme mere. Lili Elbe var pludselig rejst til Dresden. Det var vel det bedste. 48 år gammel døde Lili Elbe den 13. september 1931 på “Frauenklinik” og er begravet i Dresden på Trinitatis-kirkegårdenWritten as one word without a hyphen in Paradiset er ikke til salg.. Jeg har hørt, at graven er meget forfalden, gravstenen er nemlig væltet, men jeg har også hørt, at man tænker på at sætte den i stand igen.”
Gerda Wegener med sin italienske mand Fernando Porta – i bogen kaldet Ridolfo Feruzzi. Gerda Wegener blev betragtet som “et virkelig fænomenalt tegnetalent”. Hun vandt en position i 20’ – 30’ernes Paris som ingen anden dansk kunstner. Og, som kunsthistorikeren Else Kai Sass skriver: “På korte besøg i København duperede hun fuldstændig sine omgivelser med at optræde med en elegance og en udfordrende parisisk chic, der var hidtil ukendt her på bjerget”. Gerda Wegener døde 1940, 55 år gammel. Politikens Presse Foto. The photo, which takes up the whole page along with the caption, is credited to Politiken Press. Gerda Wegener and husband Fernando Porta fill the frame of the photo, which seems to be outside, and they are dressed for going out.

Han skrev især mange skuespil og filmmanuskripter, bl.a. var han medforfatter til Carl Th. Dreyers Vredens Dag. It captures Lili Elbe, Poul Knudsen and Gerda Wegener outside, most likely in Berlin, dressed in coats and hats.
“Fra mand til kvinde” står den dag i dag som en transsexuel bibel. Eksempelvis nævner den engelske forfatter Jan Morris i sin selvbiografi “Conundrum”, at skildringen af Andreas Sparre/Einer Wegeners transformation til Lili Elbe indvirkede på hans beslutning om at undergå kønsskifte.
Om bogens modtagelse i England fortæller Gerda Wegener i et brev fra 1933:
“KæreThere is no closing quotation mark corresponding to this. Poul,
... A propos England: SåThis is the modern spelling. The same letter is included in Paradiset er ikke til salg where the word is spelled Saa which is consistent with the ortography of 1933. har en gammel fin Englænderinde her ladet sig præsentere hos mig for at tale med mig om Lilis bogParadiset er ikke til salg has Bog (book) with a capital B which is consistent with the ortography of 1933., som for nyligt er udkommetParadiset er ikke til salg has udkommen. i England, og som skal have en stormende Succes og væreParadiset er ikke til salg has været. Dagens store Samtaleemne. Man ved i London, at det er mig, Gerda Wegener som er Grete i Bogen. Og min gamle engelske Veninde beklagede voldsomt, at jeg ikke kunne komme til London i Øjeblikket, da hun paastod, at jeg ville blive “Dagens Heltinde”.
“Poul” var Gerda Wegener og Lili Elbes fælles ven, juristen og forfatteren Poul Knudsen, som i bogen kaldes Niels Hvide.
Om baggrunden for bogens form, som måske kan forekomme lidt eksalteret og kulørt, forklarer Lili Elbe i et brev til samme Poul Knudsen:
“Lindevangen 8-10, 22.I-31.
Kære store Paul[Sic.].
Tusind Tak for Dit Brev.
Jeg skal med Sorg rette mig efter Dit Ønske og forandre Heltens Navn.
Han kommer saa til at hedde Hjalmar Hvide (senere ændret til Niels Hvide, T.R.) Du skal ikke forbavses over, at jeg skriver pænt og korrekt om en Ven – jeg hører jo ikke rigtig med i Lumskebugten herhjemme. Hvor jeg glæder mig til at høre om Vibekes Triumftur i Julen!
Den vidunderlige i Dresden hedder: Prof. Dr. Kurt Warnekros. Det staar endogsaa skrevet med dobbelt W i mit hjærteThe same letter, transcribed and translated, in the Lili Elbe Digital Archive has Hjærte. – ja, endogsaa deri graveret!
Det glæder mig meget at Herr Ervin Magnus tror paa Bogen. Men jeg maa bede dig forklare ham følgende:
Naar jeg ikke har skrevet Bogen som en Levnedsskildring er det for
/>
at faa frem, at det drejer sig om to Personer Andreas og Lili, der sjæleligt ikke hører sammen.
Det fremgaar nok mest af sidste Del, at der er Dualitet – eller var. Det er først Andreas, der fortæller om sine Erindringer til Paul, mens Andreas havde Overtaget, hvorpaa Lili fortæller Erindringer til Paul fra den Tid, hvor hun begyndte at arbejde sig frem og fik hovedpartenThe same letter, transcribed and translated, in the Lili Elbe Digital Archive has Hovedparten. af AktiverneThis word is printed as Aktierne in the same letter in Paradiset er ikke til salg, but as Aktiverne in this introduction. It is not easy to see what the handwritten letter in the Lili Elbe Digital Archive says. Aktiverne means “the assets” (of the common estate) whereas Aktierne means “the shares” as in parts of a company’s capital. The word is repeated at the end of the letter as Aktiverne here and Aktierne in Paradiset er ikke til salg. i deres Fællesbo – og til sidst Eneindehaver.
Det fremgår tydeligt af sidste Del, at det endogsaa er en absolut Livsbetingelse for Lili, at hun aandeligt intet har at skaffe med Andreas – og det store Mirakel er, at hun føler sig nyskabt – ren og jomfruelig og absolut ikke sjæleligt et Mandfolk, der er bleven til et Pigebarn!!!
Anden Del viser ogsaa, hvorledes Werner von Kreuz altid har holdt de to ude fra hinanden.
Det er Hovedpointet i Bogen, at der var to Sjæle i et Legeme – og at en genial Kirurg redder Pigebarnet ud af et fælles Skibbrud. Saa er jeg tilmed bange for, at den anden Form skulde tynge Bogen, og jeg ønsker netop at faa frem, at jeg er koket, sorgløs, overfladisk og pjanket – og det har været mig om at faa frem, at hvad der er af kunstnerisk, af Livsvisdom og alvorlig mandig Viden, kommer fra Andreas, der var Kunstner og et honnet Mandfolk, mensThe same letter, transcribed and translated, in the Lili Elbe Digital Archive has medens. min Indsats er en vis letbenet og tøset Filosofi .The same letter, transcribed and translated, in the Lili Elbe Digital Archive has an exclamation mark. (Du ser, det er i Virkeligheden en Nedskrivning af Aktiverne). Bed Herr Ervin Magnus at ville høre med Sympati på dette mit forsvarThe same letter, transcribed and translated, in the Lili Elbe Digital Archive has Forsvar. for Bogens Form.
Din stakkels Veninde
Lili”
Hellerup, den 20 juli 1988
Teit Ritzau

div.p: From Man into Woman
Lili Elbe’s Confessions
Foreword by Teit Ritzau
Skippershoved

When “From Man into Woman” was first published in 1931, it was highly controversial. The subject matter of the book, transsexuality, had been unknown to the majority of the readers of that time who no doubt considered it as a risqué story.

A transsexual person is on bad terms with his or herThe pronoun sit in the Danish text is not gendered, but this is not remarkable but simply due to grammar. The gender of the pronoun is determined by the gender of the following noun (in this case køn (gender) which is neutrum in Danish). biological gender. He wants to change his sex and like Andreas Sparre in this book he is willing to go through all kinds of procedures, surgical, medical, and cosmetic, that can change his looks and appearance. For Andreas Sparre when it comes to gender identity – understood as the view a person has of him- or herselfThis is also not gendered in the Danish text as the pronoun sig can be both feminine and masculine. as belonging to one gender or the other, regardless of which gender role you represent on the outside – he feels as a 100% woman who by “mistake” has been placed in a man’s body.

The question of gender identity has had renewed relevance today, and the interest in the extreme part of the spectrum of gender identity – intersexual, transvestites, and transsexuals – is growing. The delimitation of the feminine and the masculine has always concerned humanity but has in our time been associated with a growing narcissism – in other contexts characterised as the weakness of modern man.
“The body is not an object, it is a situation”, the French philosopher Merleau-Ponty wrote, and we have all experienced how the body has a special meaning in relation to its surroundings.

The human body can become a curse through upbringing and environment. This is particularly evident in transsexual people, as the main character of this book, who are doomed to have a body and not be a body.

But it is not only humans who have the problem of defining the boundary between the masculine and the feminine. “God”, the Jewish storyteller said, created humans in his own bisexual image. He created them as male and female because in him they were both united.
The male protagonist of the book, Andreas Sparre, was really named Einer Wegener. He was a painter and married to the well-known illustrator Gerda Wegener – in the book called Grete.
In connection with Einer Wegener’s planned sex change operation he was examined at Institut für Sexualwissenschaft

div.p: in Berlin as described in the book. The founder of this the first institute of sexology was professor Magnus Hirschfeld who is called Hardenfeld in the book. He was a pioneer within sexological research – in America referred to as the “Einstein of Sex” – and the centre of a peculiar and colourful milieu. A number of well-known cultural figures of the time flocked to his institute, among them the writer Christopher Isherwood who mentions Hirschfeld and his institute in his memoirs “Christopher and His Kind”. The film “Caberet”, incidentally, is based on Isherwood’s descriptions of Berlin.

As Hirschfeld in addition to being a sexologist was also a Jew, a pacifist, a socialist, and a homosexual, he quickly became a victim of Nazi persecution and had to go into exile. The institute was stormed by the Nazis in 1933, the records burned and the furniture destroyed. Many probably remember the documentary film shots from the Berlin of the 30s where the fanatically screaming Nazis carry a bust of Magnus Hirschfeld to the fire.

div.p: Einer Wegener underwent the final sex change operation at Frauenklinik in Dresden, and under the name Lili Elbe she then returned to Denmark. Here she met the German writer Ernst Harthern, who as a foreign correspondent had settled in Copenhagen. Harthern took it upon himself, as mentioned in the preface of the book where he signed himself Niels Hoyer, to collect Lili Elbe’s notes in preparation for a book publication. His daughter, Ruth Hanna Harthern-Thanning, who is also mentioned in the book, was 16 years old at that time. She tells the following about Lili Elbe:

“Yes, it was not her outer appearance (fox-red hair, bright red nails and mouth). No, it was her entire manner --- she was a real woman. For I had not known her as a man. It was agreed (Lili Elbe felt very lonely, I understood) that I should learn to paint with her. It was Whitsun the next day. The next morning, I left our flat in Havnegade 47. With a light heart I walked through the sunny Nyhavn to Kongens Nytorv and went on by tram to Valby where this Elbe had taken shelter in an attic flat in a nice villa with nice people. She had already put out an easel on which a prepared stretched canvas was placed, besides this there was paint and everything else that belonged to painting.

In the few days of her life a self-portrait and two still lives materialised. It was probably also for other reasons that she let me in for the poor womanMenneske in the Danish text is not gendered. had fallen deeply in love with her benefactor: the professor from “Frauenklinik” in Dresden.

Terribly sad. It was a good thing that already then, I so clearly understood that you cannot send such letters. What this doctor had done with that operation was perhaps not quite beneficial for this unhappy person. She struggled endlessly with herself.

She thought I was embarrassed when I translated her love letters to him from Danish into German. In fact, I changed them into being only kind letters of thanks. Of course, it had to be unpleasant for the doctor. It did not amount to many letters.

Suddenly she asked me not to come anymore. Lili Elbe had suddenly gone to Dresden. That was probably the best thing. At the age of 48 Lile Elbe died on the 13 September 1931 at “Frauenklinik” and is buried in Dresden at the Trinitatis cemetery. I have heard that the grave is in a state of great disrepair, that is the headstone has been turned over, but I have also heard that they are considering restoring it again.”

figDesc.hi: Gerda Wegener with her Italian husband Fernando Porta – called Ridolfo Feruzzi in the book.Gerda Wegener was considered “a really phenomenal drawing talent”. She won a position in Paris of the 20s and 30s like no other Danish artist. And as the art historian Else Kai Sass writes: “On short visits in Copenhagen she completely impressed her surroundings by conducting herself with an elegance and a provocative Parisian chic that was so far unknown in these partsThe Danish text has her på bjerget (literally: here on the mountain) which is difficult to translate. It refers to the satirical play Erasmus Montanus (1731) by the Danish/Norwegian writer Ludvig Holberg (1684-1754). The phrase “here on the mountain” is used by the people of the village called “Bjerget” in connection with their established beliefs which in the play exclude new ideas. The reference is so common in Danish that it is almost a ‘dead metaphor’..” Gerda Wegener died in 1940, at the age of 55. Politiken Press Photo.

div.p: “From Man into Woman” stands as a transsexual bible even today. As an example, the English writer Jan Morris in her autobiography “Conundrum” mentions that the description of Andreas Sparre/Einer Wegener’s transformation into Lili Elbe affected her decision to undergo a sex change.
About the reception of the book in England Gerda Wegener relates in a letter from 1933:
““Dear Poul,

… Speaking of England: An old English lady has let herself be introduced to me here to talk to me about Lili’s Book that has recently been published in England and is supposed to be a tremendous success and the main subject of conversation of the day. It is known in London that it is me, Gerda Wegener, who is Grete in the book. And my old English friend deeply regretted that I was not able to come to London at the moment as she claimed that I would be “the heroine of the day”.
“Poul” was Gerda Wegener and Lili Elbe’s mutual friend, the lawyer and writer Poul Knudsen who is called Niels Hvide in the book.
About the reason for the form of the book, which may seem a little overwrought and sensational, Lili Elbe explains in a letter to the said Poul Knudsen:
“Lindevangen 8-10, 22.I-31.
Dear big Paul.
Thank you so much for your letter.
It is with regret that I will comply with your wish and change the name of the hero.

He will then be called Hjalmar Hvide (later changed to Niels Hvide, T.R.) Do not be surprised that I write nicely and correctly about a friend – I do not really belong to the in crowd at home. How I look forward to hearing about Vibeke’s triumphal trip during Christmas!
The name of the wonderful person in Dresden is Prof. Kurt Warnekros. It is even written with a W in my heart – yes even therein engraved!
I am very pleased that Mr. Ervin Magnus believes in the book. But I must ask you to explain the following to him:
When I have not written the book as a biography it is to
make it clear that it is about two people Andreas and Lili who are not mentally connected.

It is probably most apparent from the last part that there is a duality – or was. First it is Andreas who tells Poul his memories from when Andreas was dominant after which Lili tells Poul memories from the time when she began to work her way forward and got the greater part of the assets in their common estate – and eventually became the sole proprietor.

It appears clearly from the last part that it is even of absolutely vital importance to Lili that spiritually she has nothing to do with Andreas – and the great miracle is that she feels reborn – pure and virginal – and mentally absolutely not a man who has become a girl!!!
The second part also shows how Werner von Kreuz has always distinguished between the two.

The main point of the book is that there were two souls in one body – and that a brilliant surgeon saves the girl from a joint shipwreck. I am also afraid that the other form would weigh down the book and I precisely wish to show that I am coquettish, carefree, superficial and silly – and it has been important to me to show that what there is of artistic, philosophical, and serious male knowledge, comes from Andreas who was an artist and an honourable man while my contribution is a certain shallow and girlish philosophy. (You see, it is really a devaluation of the assets). Ask Mr. Ervin Magnus to listen with sympathy to this my defence of the form of the book.
Your poor little friend
Lili”
Hellerup, 20 July 1988
